Production stands first among them like some primordial force. It begins with the watching, always the watching. Men in offices studying the numbers on screens like augurs reading entrails, trying to divine what the people want. The market speaks in whispers and shouts and they who would survive must learn its tongue. Then comes the deciding. What to make and how much and where to make it. Choosing wrong can bleed a company dry sure as any wound.

He remembered the time at Walmart and Target both, them places with their books of rules thick as bibles. Every little thing wrote down just so. How to wear the clothes they gave you, how to take the boxes off the trucks. Everything had its way and its place. The companies knew that chaos was always waiting, patient as death, and only order could keep it at bay.

Supply comes after, like the shadow of production. Men in rooms making choices about what they can do and what they must let others do. Every factory has its own ways, its own machines humming in the fluorescent light, its own hands moving in ancient rhythms. Sometimes they send the work away to other places, chasing that thing they call velocity. Velocity, he thought. Just a fancy word for being quick and being cheap all at once, like it was something you could catch and hold.

The managers move through it all like priests of some new religion, making their choices, watching the numbers dance across their screens. They parse the mysteries of supply and demand like old prophets reading signs in the desert sky. And always the chain moves on, endless as a river, carrying the things of the world from hand to hand through the darkness of time.

They come in the night these books of old. Victorian they called them. Full of words and gilt and fancy folk who dined with silver and lived in houses tall as God. But there was two that walked a different path. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights. Dark books. Strange books. Books that carried mystery in their bones like some old disease that wont let go. Made the people in them more real somehow. More true.

In Oliver there was dreams. Dark dreams that come like black water rising. The boy dreaming of Sikes and Crackit arguing, their words real as knife blades in the night. Then the gunshot. Then the screaming. Lights like fever dreams dancing in his head while something drug him away through the dark. Through it all the pain come. Come and stayed. Like it had found a home in him and meant to stay forever.

These dreams they showed what the boy was inside. What ate at him in the deep night. How he knew things aint right but couldn't do nothing about it. When they shot him he lived it twice. Once in the world and once in his head. In the dream he was powerless. Some force moving him like a puppet on strings while pain gnawed at him steady as hunger. Pain that weren't sharp no more but dull like an old knife. Mixed up with fear now instead of surprise.

The boy had no control. Never did. Someone else's will moving him through the world like a leaf in the wind. The shooting showed it plain. Even with death coming he couldn't fight. Like old Fagin had broke something in him. Something that used to know how to struggle against the dark. Now he just let it come. Let it take him where it would.

Time itself got strange. Day becoming night becoming day again. No difference between them anymore. Just long dark silence and hours that ran like water through your fingers. No catching them. No holding on.

There was a time I minded children. Not my own but others. Small ones with dark eyes who couldn't read the words before them. One boy, Adrian they called him, struggled worse than most. He'd stare at the letters like they were dead things. Some marks he knew and others were foreign to him like tracks in snow that told no story he could read.

The boy spoke English pure as winter air but something was wrong in him. You could see it in how his eyes moved across the page, searching, lost. His people came from south of here where the language was different but that wasn't it. Not all of it.

His mother came one day. She stood in the doorway like a dark bird, speaking no English, only the tongue of her homeland. We traded broken words, her Spanish and mine mixing like oil and water, but it was enough. The truth hit me then like a hammer blow. The boy could read fine enough but the letters were strangers to him. The English alphabet might as well have been hieroglyphs carved in stone.

I tell this tale not for its own sake but for what lies beneath. Here in California we got us a wall between languages, invisible but real as concrete. Sometimes it hides in plain sight. A child might speak English clean as morning but still stumble when the words are laid before him on the page. We all know this truth but knowing ain't fixing.

For Adrian the path was clear enough. Teach him his letters, show him how the sounds matched up. But for them that barely speak English at all, there ain't no simple answer. Dual language learning, immersion, tutors, ESL - none of these alone is enough. Like a house needs all its walls, we need all these things together.

The dual language way, that's something worth considering. Not just for them that speak Spanish first but for all of them. Studies show these children do better than their peers, though some folk fear it's wasting time and money. That fear's as hollow as a dead tree. Put these programs in every classroom and watch them all grow stronger. Don't need every teacher speaking two tongues neither. Just need some folk who can bridge that gap, help them cross that river from one language to the other.

Most all of us get told when we're young that there's somethin out there bigger than ourselves. Bigger than what we can know. Some get sent off to learn about it in buildings with crosses hung on em and some to temples with stars and some just look inside themselves for whatever truth might be there. Most take to the god their momma and daddy gave em but others cast it off like a snake sheds its skin, saying there aint nothing in this world except what they can see with their own eyes. We pick up beliefs like a man picks up stones, holding em for a spell then casting em aside for different ones. Whatever path we take we're all just trying to find our way through it. Looking for some kind of light in all that darkness. Something to lead us out.

My daddy told me once he loved cardinals best of all the birds. We was sitting on the porch, listening to the rain beating down on that old tin roof while we smoked. The gutters was running over, drowning them little flowers my momma had planted years back. He just stared out into that rain like he was looking for something that wasnt there no more. He'd gotten real thin by then. His clothes just hanging on him like they was hung on a wire fence. His hair had gone mostly too, just wisps of what used to be. He wouldnt look at me. I wanted to tell him how much I'd miss him but the words wouldnt come cause saying em would make it all too real. So I just hugged him and moved my chair closer and we both watched that June rain falling in the dark.

He died that December. Five days after I turned twenty-two. The doctors had given him medicine that didnt help none except to keep him suffering longer than he should of. I lay in my bed them nights wondering what kind of God would do such a thing. I said no prayers. If there was a God up there he wasnt listening to the likes of me no more.

I didnt want to watch him go. So I didnt. Couldnt bear to see the life that made me while it was ending. I wanted to keep him like he was. Like he lived. Not like he died. I knew him better than all of em did and knew he wouldnt want his boy watching him slip away. So I just lay there in my bed. Curled up like some wounded animal. Waiting three days for word that never came.

Nobody even called to tell me he was gone.

He come riding out of the east, John Taylor of Caroline did, bearing with him notions of Republic and freedom that would mark him in the years to come. A man of the soil first and foremost though his hands had known both dirt and politics and his mind knew the weight of both. The land shaped him and his thoughts on liberty and governance flowed from that selfsame earth like water from a spring.

The man believed America stood at a crossroads where no traditions held sway and where men might build something pure and true from nothing but their own conviction. Natural rights, he said, was like a string of beads. Break one and watch the rest scatter to the wind. These things must stand beyond the reach of any government hand. He spoke of how in nature the strong and cunning prospered but civilization must find another way.

Taylor knew the darkness that dwelt in men's hearts. Good and evil to him were fixed as stars. Government being the work of men must carry both their virtues and their sins, he wrote in those days. Good principles protected what a man owned, made the land prosper, kept the moneylenders at bay. Self-interest drove all men but turned poison when it led to parasites feeding off the common good. Even the best government needed watching like a wolf at the door.

Like others of his kind he held to the Constitution's words strict and true. The federal power must be kept small, bound tight by chains of law. A costly government turns tyrant quick as summer lightning, he'd say. But words alone could corrupt without the spirit that gave them life. The Declaration was his true north star, showing separate sovereign states and not one nation bound.

He saw the land and the men who worked it as the bedrock of all liberty. His thoughts on sovereignty and law and courts all flowed from this well. The old agriculturalist knew that freedom grew from the soil like wheat from seed, and all his days he fought to keep that harvest pure.

He stood there staring down. Empty and cold and studying what lay before him without thought or feeling or connection to any deeper meaning that might have dwelt in the depths of his mind. Thoughts came and went like wind through dead grass. His consciousness moved like water over stone, smooth and purposeless.

He remembered a book. An old thing with dogeared pages that spoke of how to make marks on paper seem real. The artist who'd told him of it was long dead now. The book taught about frames. How to section off the world into pieces small enough for a man to understand. How to take the vastness of what lay before you and cut it down to size. Like taking a knife to God's own canvas.

But there was no frame for this. No way to section off what lay before him in that porcelain bowl. It was what it was and nothing more. Picasso had his blues and Monet his greens but this was brown. Deep and dark and final. The color of the earth when it takes back what's its own.

His fingers found the handle. Cold chrome against skin. Muscles tensed and relaxed like a gunfighter's before the draw. Water moved in its ancient circles, clear as tears. Matter broke away and scattered like ash in the wind. He pulled the handle again. Harder this time. Desperate maybe. But the brown mass clung there like something dead that refused to be buried.

He stood in his green tie that choked at his throat like a hangman's rope. Feet planted like a man about to be shot. The mop beside him a witness to what was to come. The fluorescent lights of the Rite Aid bathroom hummed overhead like the voice of some minor god. He pulled paper from the roll and wrapped his hand like a man wrapping a wound. Then he reached down into those cold waters like a man reaching into his own grave.

They die behind the wheel. Young ones. Not yet grown. The statistics tell their tale in numbers cold and merciless as winter. The doctors at the National Institute speak of brains not yet ready, synapses still forming in the dark chambers of youth. But there's more to it than that. More than just the raw inexperience that sends metal coffins spinning off blacktops and rolling through ditches in the dead of night.

He'd seen them. The young ones. Packed like cattle in their father's cars, laughing and burning rubber down empty streets. The California men who study such things drew lines between the numbers. Between the dead and the living. Between the age of the passenger and the metal twisted round telephone poles.

The state men tried to fix it with paper laws. Provisional licenses they called them. Times when the young could drive and times when they couldn't. But paper burns and laws are just words written in ash.

The truth was simpler. Darker. The youngest ones weren't ready. Not by any measure man could devise. Zuckerman, the mind doctor, he knew. Even eighteen summers wasn't enough. They sought the thrill like animals seeking water in drought. The rush of speed and the taste of danger sweet as stolen wine on their tongues.

More would die. That was certain as sunrise. The children of the boom times were coming of age and they'd flood the roads like locusts. Millions strong by 2010. Each one carrying death in their pocket like a lucky coin.

The answer lay in waiting. Let them learn in school yards and parking lots but keep them from the wheel until eighteen winters had passed. Make them prove themselves under watching eyes. Six hours behind the wheel and fifty more with someone who'd seen enough sunsets to know better. Make it the same in every state, from sea to shining sea. One law for all the young.

It wasn't new thinking. Wasn't even original. But neither was death, and it kept coming all the same.

He sat at the desk studying the papers before him, documents yellowed and curled at the edges like old photographs. Words about the brain and how it fails us. Central Auditory Processing Disorder, they called it. CAPD. Letters that meant nothing and everything to them that suffered it.

The disorder lived in the spaces between hearing and knowing. In the neural pathways where sound becomes meaning. These people could hear just fine but their brains betrayed them, scrambling the signals like a radio caught between stations. Not deaf but something else. Something worse maybe.

He remembered the first ones who found it, Italian doctors in the old world. Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari. Names like incantations. They worked with broken children in 1954, children whose ears worked but whose minds couldn't parse the world's cacophony. Kimura came later with his tests, splitting sounds between ears like a man splitting wood.

The afflicted ones walked through the world like ghosts. Couldn't tell where sounds came from. Couldn't separate one voice from another in a crowd. Couldn't hear the mockery in a voice or the love in it neither. Sound washed over them like waves, drowning meaning in its wake.

They tested for it now with machines and questionnaires. Audiologists and speech doctors watching patients like scientists watch rats in a maze. No single test could catch it. No one knew what caused it. They'd play sounds in both ears at once and ask what was heard, recording the signals that bounced around inside the skull like echoes in a cave.

The science was imperfect. Like trying to catch smoke in your hands. The doctors watched and waited and measured but still they couldn't say why some brains betrayed their owners this way. Why some folks could hear the world but couldn't understand what it was telling them.

He thought about how the world must look to them. All sound and fury signifying nothing. Walking through life like being underwater, everything muffled and strange. The brain playing tricks like a devil with a deck of cards.

He sat there in the dim light of the office thinking on what path to follow. Social work. The word itself carried weight like old stones. Children who had been broke and bent by the ones meant to shelter them. Families gone wrong in the head and heart both. Service and respect and ethics. Words that meant something once and would mean something again if he had his way.

He remembered them all. The lost ones in high school and after. Running from things they couldn't name. Drowning their demons in whatever poison they could find. That's what led him to study the mind at Piedmont. Learning the ways people break and mend and break again.

Then there was the boy. Sixteen and scared and perched on a stranger's couch like a wounded bird. Running from hands that should have loved but chose to harm instead. He went to that house the next day. Talked to the law standing in that yard. Parents inside making excuses like they always do. Simple disputes they called it. Nothing simple about it. That's when he knew what path lay before him.

Justice was another matter. A word that carried different weight for different folk. Society claiming to care for the individual while grinding down anyone who stood apart. He never did cotton to that. Through all his schooling he fought against the sameness they tried to press on him. Hair bright as poison. Metal in his ears past what folks thought proper. Standing with them that society said weren't natural or right. Fighting the old hatreds wherever they showed their face.

The world had gone wrong somewhere. Turned mean and small. But there were still those who'd stand against it. Still those who'd help the broken ones. Still those who'd fight for what's right even when right was hard to find in all the darkness. He aimed to be one of them. That's all a man could do in times like these.

Dark now and the mind turns to sleep and the absence of it. To the deep biological rhythms that govern us like some ancient timepiece buried in the flesh. There are models they say. Ways of seeing. The biological and the sociocultural lying there in the dark like twin specters haunting the edges of consciousness.

Sleep comes or it dont. Some nights the darkness stretches endless and the mind wont quiet and you lie there counting the hours like beads on a rosary. They got names for it now. Classifications. Primary disorders and secondary ones and ones that aint got proper names at all. Dyssomnias. Parasomnias. Words that taste of dust and medical texts. But what they mean is simple enough. The inability to sleep or to stay awake or to keep from walking in your sleep like some creature possessed.

Deep in the hypothalamus there are neurons that decide whether we wake or sleep. Little messengers carrying their cargo of orexin through the brain like workers in some vast biological factory. They found it first in mice. Always the mice. The GABAB receptors sitting there like gatekeepers, deciding who passes and who dont. Give them the right signal and sleep comes. Block them and the mind stays wakeful. Simple as that. Or maybe not so simple.

The scientists talk about phenotypes and agonists and receptor sites but what they're really talking about is inheritance. The dark gift passed down through blood and bone from parent to child. Some folks just born to lie awake while the rest of the world sleeps. Born to watch the darkness gather and spread like ink across a page. And what that means in the real world aint hard to figure. Try holding down a job when you cant sleep. Try learning when your mind is full of cotton and static. Try living in a world built for people who close their eyes at night and find peace.

They got studies. Always more studies. But what they really mean is that some folks is cursed to wakefulness and some aint. And all the scientific words in the world dont change that simple truth.

Been here at University Park going on three years now. The getting around weighs heavy. That first year they put me in East Halls, far out on the edge of things where the wind comes raw across empty ballfields and the stadium stands black against the sky. The walking was hard. Twenty-five minutes or more to Willard if the weather held, longer when it didnt. And the weather rarely held in State College.

Talked once with a man who'd walked these grounds before. Not much older than me but he spoke of vast empty spaces where now buildings rose like concrete mountains. New Creamery. Health services. Apartment blocks lined up like headstones. The campus growing like some mindless thing, consuming ground, making the walking harder with each passing season. What's to be done about the getting around? The bicycle stands as answer but it aint enough by itself. Students got to ride them and the grounds got to be made right for the riding.

Friend of mine took up the bike again after years without. Said he couldn't reckon why he'd ever quit. Said it was the only true way to move across this world. Good for the body and efficient besides. Bowl of morning gruel and some honest sweat'll carry you thirty miles or more. Living off campus now myself, far as any dorm. Getting that bike was the smartest thing I done. Classes in Thomas building, twenty-five minutes walking if you're lucky. On the bike it's five minutes if you're willing to push. Only trouble is Pollock Road. Straightest shot there is but mean country to cross, bike or no.

Walking's got its merits true enough but time aint one of them. Without the bike there'd be nothing but walking and I cant spare the hours. Thirty, forty minutes extra every day just getting to Thomas. Two and a half hours gone from every week, vanished like smoke. Add in all the other walking - classes, meetings, everything else a body's got to do - and time bleeds away like water in sand.

The road goes ever on. The buildings rise. The campus spreads like some dark stain across the valley. But the bicycle remains, waiting patient as stone for them as would use it. Waiting to carry us through this concrete wilderness we built ourselves.

He sat there in the dim light reading the words about the world that was. The book spoke of a man named Huxley who saw what was coming long before others did. Who wrote of a world where men were no more than cattle. Where they were bred and shaped and molded like clay figures in some godless kiln. Each made the same. Each the same as the last. A world of numbers and machines and the cold mathematics of control.

The words spoke of classes of men. Of Alphas and Betas and the rest below them like rungs on some terrible ladder descending into darkness. Each believing they were content. Each believing they were free. But they weren't free. They were prisoners who didn't know they were in chains. Who couldn't feel the iron that bound them.

He thought about how they lived in that world. No love between them. No real feeling at all. Just the endless pursuit of pleasure like animals rutting in the dirt. The men speaking of women like they were nothing but flesh. The women speaking of coupling like it was no more meaningful than eating or sleeping. All of them moving through their days like sleepwalkers. Like the dead.

The Controller watched over them all. Like some dark god in a high tower. Keeping them docile with drugs and pleasure and empty words pumped into their heads while they slept. Words that told them to buy and spend and want and need. Never to think. Never to question. Never to wake up from the dream they were living.

He thought about how the ones at the bottom never knew they were at the bottom. How they were told they were special and important so long as they kept working and buying and doing what they were told. Like sheep being led to slaughter but thinking they were going to paradise.

The words spoke of Marx too. Of how he saw this coming in his own way. How he knew that men would be made blind to their own chains. How they would learn to love their prison if you built it right. If you made it shine bright enough.

He closed the book and sat there in the growing dark. Thinking about how sometimes a man can see the future coming like a storm on the horizon. Dark and terrible and true.

Four years back I set to learning of Islam at the college. Dark questions hung in that room like smoke, chief among them whether Islam bore violence in its heart. The query weighs heavier now than it did then. Since those towers fell I watched how the papers and screens shifted like wind-blown ash from hatred to a strange sort of reverence. Back then none would have believed a man named Barack Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his veins, could stand for president of this land.

The Prophet's tale gnaws at me. What's writ of Muhammad stands against what history speaks of him. In my knowing he was a man of the sword, bringing tribes to heel and marking their foreheads with his faith. Yet these pages paint him a lamb, humbled and misunderstood, while converts came to him like moths to flame, seeing truth in his words.

There's something that mirrors Christ in these tales, something that makes the blood run cold. They tell how he took meat and milk and made it more, feeding forty men. The words are crafted careful-like, showing him humble, needing no proof of his calling, living quiet among his miracles. This is the deepest wrong, for it dims the light of Jesus, stealing His glory to dress another man.

The book carries tales meant to witness how men came willing to Islam, but they're hollow things, passed mouth to mouth like stories round a fire. Each teller claims he heard it from another who heard it from another still, till the truth is thin as smoke. They meant these chains of telling to strengthen their words but they only made them weaker, like a rope frayed to breaking.

What burns worst is how they dress Muhammad in robes of gentleness and wisdom, making him holy and meek. But history speaks other words, darker words, and I wonder if those who follow him now know the true path he walked to power, marked in blood and iron across the sands.

They'd left his words behind like tracks in the sand, washed away by time and the tides of men's thoughts that came after. The truth of it lay bare and cold as bones in the desert. Each passing year drew them further from what he'd meant, like a compass needle spinning wild and lost from true north.

The world now carried some new thing in it. A awakening maybe. Progressive notions spreading like wildfire through dry timber while the old guard stood fast against change, clutching their father's beliefs like old photographs yellowed and creased. But their numbers had grown thin. Time would see to that.

Among the faithful there stirred a hunger. A need to strip away the layers men had wrapped around his words like burial cloths, seeking what lay beneath. It would come slow as winter thaw but sure as death: a great undoing. The theological clock spinning backwards through time, peeling away doctrine like dead skin until nothing remained but his raw truth, spoken before others claimed to speak for him.

When it came it would sweep through the old countries like a dust storm, leaving changed men in its wake. The church would abide, steering souls through the tempest, but something else would happen. The wild spread of beliefs would draw back together like mercury, forming one pure silver drop. Different tongues speaking the same words. Different paths leading to the same door.

History showed such reversals. Rome that once fed Christians to lions later knelt before the cross. A nation built on slavery now led by the sons of slaves. The wheel turns and what was down comes up again.

They'd read his words anew, seeing through the literal to the truth beneath, like looking past the surface of still water to the depths below. But first they had to understand what came before, back when there was only Judaism under Roman rule, when the faithful split like light through a prism - Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots and the common folk who worked the land and watched and waited.

They was greedy souls all of them. Deep in their hearts where the darkness dwells and where no light could reach. Each man lookin out for hisself and damn the rest to whatever hell they might find. The Jungle showed it plain as day and there wasnt no denyin it. Them factory owners and their managers stood atop their empire of bone and blood and looked down on the masses below like gods in their heaven.

Them great factories rose up black against the sky like monuments to man's own wickedness. The chimneys belched forth their poison, streams of smoke writhin like serpents across the horizon till they disappeared into nothin. The owners they didnt care none about what damage they wrought. Not to man nor beast nor the very earth itself. The waste from them stockyards run thick with blood and worse, poolin in ditches and drainin into the ground like some unholy communion.

The workers was just meat to them. Numbers on a page. Expendable as the hogs they butchered. There aint no loyalty in a place where a dollar holds more worth than a man's life, one fella said. They'd work em till they dropped and then cast em aside like spent shells. No warnin. No mercy. Just the cold calculation of profit and loss written in ledgers stained with the blood of the workin poor.

Weren't no law to protect em neither. Not then. The factories was kingdoms unto themselves and them that ruled em was cruel sovereigns indeed. They drove their subjects harder and harder, crackin the whip till flesh gave way to bone. The people what lived there in them shadowlands round Packingtown, they was expected to endure. To suffer. To die. Wasnt no help comin. The unions that formed was just wolves in different clothin, feedin off the desperation of them they claimed to protect.

They called em slaves and that's what they was. A mass of foreign flesh hangin by threads over the abyss of starvation, their very lives dependent on the whims of men who was brutal as any slave driver that ever lived. In such darkness immorality bloomed like some poisonous flower, inevitable as sunrise, prevalent as death itself. That's what the system bred. That's what it fed on. The bones of the poor ground to dust beneath the wheels of progress.

He walked through the pages of old books seeking Thulé like a man seeking water in the wastes. The words lay there dead and cold on yellowed paper. Virgil had writ of it first they said. Some frozen place beyond the edges of maps where nothing lived and nothing died. But there was another who knew of such places. A German. His books carried across black waters in the holds of darker ships.

The boy Poe he knew these words. Knew them like he knew the taste of spirits burning down his throat in the midnight hours. Knew them like he knew the faces of the dead. There was this German Goethe who wrote of kings and death and love lost to the void. Wrote of a king whose woman died and left him nothing but a cup to drink his grief from. The king he gave away his kingdom piece by piece save for that cup that cup that cup until at last he stood upon the edge of all things and cast it into the waters below. Then he closed his eyes and followed after.

These were the stories that fed the darkness in Poe's mind. Fed it like wood feeds fire until it blazed up and scorched the pages he put his pen to. He wrote of Thulé twice. Once in a tale of pits and pendulums and once in verses that spoke of dreams. But these were not sweet dreams. No. These were dreams of ash and bone where dead friends walked and colors bled away to grey and nothing was as it seemed or should be.

You could lay these words side by side. The German's king and Poe's dreamer. Same darkness. Same loss. Same emptiness eating at the edges of the world. Like brothers separated by an ocean of time and ink but carrying the same blood in their veins. The same poison in their cups.

Poe knew of Goethe. Had to know. The German's words were everywhere then like birds scattered by a storm. And Tennyson. Tennyson who Poe held high spoke of him. Said things that echoed in the chambers of Poe's mind until they found their way onto his pages transformed into something darker still. Something that bore his mark like a brand burned into flesh.

The law spoke of malice and rights and obligations but the store manager knew none of these things. He sat in his office eating while the applesauce lay spilled across the cold tile floor like some pale viscous blood. The fluorescent lights cast their sickly glow upon it. Twice they came to him. First Wayne and then the Haddigan woman. Each time he waved them away like bothersome flies, said he had no time for such things, though time was all he had in abundance as he sat there shoveling food into his mouth.

The woman who fell came after. Palmer was her name though names meant little now. She lay there on the floor where five others had fallen before her in that cursed year of 2009, her back twisted and broken like a sapling in a storm. The law spoke of conscious disregard and despicable conduct but these were just words written in books by men who had never watched a person fall, never heard the wet sound of flesh meeting tile, never seen the way the fluorescent lights reflected off spilled applesauce like moon on water.

The judge would have to decide if this warranted punishment beyond mere compensation. The California code spoke in cold terms - oppression, fraud, malice. Section 3294 subsection a, as if such clinical precision could capture the moment when a man chooses his dinner over another's safety. The courts had seen such things before. They knew that malice lived in the space between knowing and doing, in that moment when a man becomes aware of danger and chooses to let it be.

Six times they had fallen in that store. Six times the floor had reached up to claim them. And still the manager sat in his office, eating. The law would have its say but the truth was simpler than statutes. A man had chosen himself over others. Had known what might come and let it come anyway. The courts would speak of willful and conscious disregard but what they meant was this: a man who would watch others fall while he ate his dinner in peace.

The wanting came like a fever. Started when she was fourteen and never left, not even three years on. Not a thing she needed but a person, though no boy ever stirred her blood. They came round sure enough, awkward and fumbling in their courtship like blind animals in the night, but she felt nothing. She studied this peculiarity like some old text written in a dead language, turning it over in her mind year after year but finding no truth in it.

The house stood quiet most days. Her folks were peaceful people who moved through rooms like ghosts, their arguments rare as rain in drought. When words did come they were about the girl's wild spirit, untamed and burning bright against their pale existence. She carried something fierce in her that set her apart from their quiet ways, yet folk were drawn to her like moths to flame.

The scream tore through the silence like a blade. Kitchen way. Her mother's voice twisted into something raw and wrong. The girl's boots scraped floorboards as she ran, heart hammering against ribs. Mama lay crumpled on cold tile, each breath carrying pain like a curse. The girl knelt beside her, hands hovering uncertain. Hospital, her mother whispered through clenched teeth. The word came broken and desperate.

The girl gathered her mother up, thankful for the strength in her arms built from years of labor. Carried her like something precious and fragile to the waiting car, laid her across the backseat. The hospital rose up ahead like some concrete monster waiting to swallow them whole.

Inside smelled of death and chemicals and fear but the girl noticed none of it, her world narrowed to her mother's pain. She called out and white-coated figures appeared from nowhere, wheeling out a stretcher like a funeral bier. They took her mother away down fluorescent-lit corridors while the girl stood helpless, watching the space where she had been.

Later they told her about the stepstool, the high cabinet, the reaching. How gravity claims all things in the end. The vase she'd been reaching for lay shattered on the kitchen floor, forgotten in the chaos that followed.

They set out to find truth in numbers and blood. The women, all of them nurses, seventy four thousand eight hundred and eighty six of them scattered across eleven states like wind-blown seeds. None had the heart sickness or the sugar disease when they began. They were young then, thirty eight to sixty three years old, though time would mark them same as it marks all things living.

The Mediterranean way they called it. Ancient as the stones there. Fruits and grains and fish from the old waters. The flesh of beasts used sparingly. Oil pressed from olives. Wine in moderation like the old ones drank. Six times over twenty years they wrote down what passed their lips, documented in ledgers like cemetery plots. Most stayed true to the telling, year after year, their words becoming numbers becoming truth.

The counters of the dead kept their books well. When a heart failed or a vessel burst in the brain they knew. They confirmed it in hospital records or death papers or the cold tables where the dead lay opened. Some they called probable when no proof could be found but they counted them too, these ghosts in the data.

They measured everything. Weight and smoke and pills. Whether the women's cycles still came or had stopped like dried streams. Whether they moved their bodies in leisure or sat still as stones. The numbers grew like cities of paper.

Twenty years passed. Two thousand three hundred ninety one hearts failed. One thousand seven hundred sixty three minds drowned in their own rivers of blood. One thousand seventy seven souls crossed over from these causes combined. But those who ate like the ancients ate, who followed the old ways, they endured. Their hearts stayed stronger, their blood flowed true. The numbers spoke clear as bones in the desert - eating as their ancestors ate meant walking longer in the light.

The counters of the dead had found their truth. It lay in olive groves and fishing boats and bread baked from ancient grain. It lay in the wisdom of the old ones who knew how to eat, how to live, how to keep death waiting a little longer at the door.

The cardboard sign held aloft in her hands spoke of Hitler and Burma. Just words scrawled in black marker but they carried weight like stone tablets. The girl who'd once played in that movie about the pregnant child stood alone at the corner where the streets met. The wind taking at her coat.

Burma. Myanmar they called it now. A place of soldiers and death and temples rising out of the morning mist like ancient bones. The junta had come in the night with their rifles and their doctrine and they'd stayed. Soldiers walking the streets like prophets of some new dead god. The year was 2007 when the monks came. Orange robes like flame against the gray concrete. They called it the Saffron Revolution but revolutions dont always end in victory. Sometimes they end in blood.

The military came for them in the dark. Ransacking the temples like vandals in some forgotten age. They drove out the foreign writers and killed a Japanese man for nothing more than holding a camera. His name was Kenji Nagai and his blood ran into the gutters like all the rest. They said thirteen dead but a soldier who'd fled told different tales. Bodies stacked like cordwood. Thousands maybe. Who could say.

It was an old story. Old as time itself. The Romans had done it. The Japanese too. Even now they sat in their towers and talked to preachers about god and money and power while the world burned below. Men who would be kings. Men who would be gods.

In China they'd gathered in the square. Students mostly. Carrying their ideas like torches. The government said hundreds died. The Red Cross said thousands. In Rwanda they killed with machetes. Neighbor against neighbor. Brother against brother. And before that the Reich had come with their trains and their camps and their cold precision. Loading families into cattle cars. Sorting the living from the soon to be dead. Writing numbers on skin like they were counting livestock. Loading them into ovens like so much cordwood.

All of it written in blood. All of it carried on the wind like ash. The girl stood on the corner holding her sign and watched the cars pass and perhaps she knew what we all knew. That evil never dies. It just changes its name and waits.

He sat there at that grand piano like some dark prophet of old, fingers hovering above the ivory keys worn smooth by time and the ceaseless pressing of notes into the night. Duke they called him and duke he was of that realm of sound and fury that men named jazz. His legacy wasnt in the playing though. No. It was in the way he shaped those sounds through the years, through the men who came and went like wraiths through his orchestra, each leaving behind some piece of their soul in the music.

The piano parts lay quiet in them compositions like some sleeping beast. But Lord how he wrote. Wrote like a man possessed of demons or angels nobody could say which. Created frameworks vast and terrible where them soloists could wander free as wild horses, yet all the while contained within the borders he'd drawn up with ink black as midnight. Each piece carried the mark of the men who played it, like fingerprints left in wet clay that hardened into something permanent and true.

That piece they called Creole Love Call showed what he could do with just a voice. Used it like it was another horn in the section, no words to weigh it down. Six parts it had, like chambers in some great mechanical heart. First the voice crying out smooth as silk then turning rough as sin, them reeds answering back like lost souls. Then that muted trumpet speaking blue notes into the darkness. High clarinet soaring above it all while the piano whispered underneath. The full band rising up like a storm in the fourth part, brass and reeds calling back and forth across some great divide. Fifth part building like the apocalypse itself with them reeds screaming high and the rest of the band marking time like a congregation waiting for judgment. Last part bringing it all back home, voice growling like some beast of the night, before that trombone ended it all with a sound like the gates of hell swinging shut.

Hot and Bothered came next year, Bubber Miley's trumpet crying out and Baby Cox's voice answering like they was speaking some language lost to man since babel fell. Then It Don't Mean a Thing where Tricky Sam Nanton made that trombone moan like a soul in torment introducing the melody that would echo through the years like a ghost that cant find rest. This was the sound of America speaking in tongues nobody knew they had till Duke gave them voice.

They come to us like ghosts from the deep time, these shells. Spiraling through darkness and void, through the countless millennia that shaped them. Each one carrying the marks of its making like some ancient testament writ in calcium and time.

He studied the shell in his hand. The whorls turning inward toward some mathematical truth that no man could name. Each revolution tracking its own trajectory through space, through time. The columella standing like some calcified spine down which all measurements must pass. He thought about the creature that had made it. Gone now to dust or deep water or both. Its life recorded only in these spiral equations that stretched back beyond memory, beyond knowing.

The last whorl stood largest of all, like the final word in some stone sermon. Above it the spire rose in diminishing circles toward heaven, toward that first point of beginning that men called apex. At the other end lay the base and between them the aperture gaped like a mouth trying to speak of its own creation.

They'd taken to counting the whorls in their own fashion. Viewing the shell from above like God might view the world, marking where that first suture began its journey outward. Drawing lines across the face of it like surveyors of some microscopic geography. Counting by quarters the revolutions it made. Each shell a map of its own making.

He thought about how the creature built its home. How each new chamber followed the last in an endless progression, each aperture plotting its course through space like some blind navigator reading coordinates in the dark. The mathematics of it all lay there in plain sight for those who knew how to read such things. Numbers that could be changed, adjusted. Like playing God with calculus and time.

These were the things they studied now. These ghost-maps of ancient life. These spiral testimonies to evolution's patient hand. Each shell a question asked across the ages. Each measurement an answer in the stone.

He studied the numbers laid bare before him like bones in the sand. Ten years gone and the dying of infants in Indonesia remained unchanged, a constant thrum of loss against the fabric of time. The country moved forward in some ways, yes. Water flowed cleaner. Waste managed better. But the children and their mothers. Their blood ran just as freely as before.

In the cities where the skilled workers dwelt some seven of ten births saw hands that knew their craft. But these hands, some belonged to the old ways. To midwives who could watch but not save when the blood came. And it came often. Dark and merciless. The numbers lied in their way, spoke half-truths that echoed in empty rooms where children lay wracked with fever and loose bowels, their mothers nowhere to be found.

The cutting of wombs to bring forth life stood at four in hundred. In the cities it was seven. In the far places where the roads turned to dust and memory it was two. The division lay stark as a knife's edge between those with means and those without. Seven and twenty percent stretched between the richest and the poorest like a canyon that could not be crossed. Money was the bridge and many had none.

The question lay before them like a dead thing in the road. Whether to strike at each wound separately or to heal the whole of the body at once. The targeted approach beckoned like a flame in darkness, promising quick victory, measurable success. But such flames cast shadows too. When money flowed to one wound the others festered. Workers followed the coin like crows to carrion, leaving behind what they knew for what would feed them. Programs multiplied like weeds after rain, choking each other with papers and forms and requests that piled like ash in empty rooms.

He looked out across the statistics and data spread before him like auguries. The numbers were just numbers but behind them lay the truth. The dying continued. The blood flowed. And somewhere in a distant village a mother clutched her child and prayed to whatever god would listen.

The sound had grown darker over them hundred years past, birthing genres upon genres till a man could scarcely count them all. Like some great beast splitting and dividing, each piece growing new limbs and new heads - rap and rock and country and jazz and folk, names that meant less with each passing season as they too split and divided and grew strange in the darkness.

Metal rose from this darkness like something ancient and terrible. Forty years it had been now, maybe more. Time was a thing that slipped away in the shadows. It came bearing emotions raw and bleeding, things that normal folk didn't speak of in the light. Dark things. True things. It spread like wildfire in drought, each spark catching and growing into its own inferno until the original flame was lost in the conflagration.

They called it heavy metal but that name meant nothing now. It had consumed too much, grown too vast. Like some great leviathan it had swallowed whole the sounds that came before it, digesting them in its burning belly until they emerged transformed. To understand this beast you had to know its heart, had to know why it wasn't just music but something more, something that moved through the world like a shadow.

It was a thing of excess, of more. More sound, more fury, more violence than what came before. The players weren't simple folk beating at strings but masters of their craft, though that craft was dark indeed. In the seventies they fed it drugs and watched it grow stranger still, using the chemicals to birth sounds that hadn't existed before, couldn't exist in the natural world. They made records that came from places beyond, used the drugs as excuses for the terrible beauty they'd created. It spoke to something in the blood that other music couldn't touch, wouldn't touch. The old composers knew it, those romantic souls who wrote their symphonies in minor keys. The darkness was always there, waiting.

When the Beatles wrote Helter Skelter they opened a door they couldn't close. It was a challenge to the Stones but it became something else, something first. The darkness had found its way in and there was no going back.

In the time before the dreamers took to their canvases with their strange visions there was Rousseau who worked in silence and in solitude crafting dreams of his own. The Dream they called it, this painting he made in 1910, and it showed a woman laid bare in wonderment at what stretched before her in sleep, though perhaps it was Rousseau's own dreams that haunted the canvas more than hers. Recognition he sought. Acceptance. The kind that comes with the nodding of heads in gilded halls where men speak in whispers about art and truth. But there was a war in him, silent and terrible. A choice between walking the path others had worn smooth or cutting his own way through the dark woods of creation.

Before you can know The Dream you got to know the man who dreamed it. Born he was in Laval in the northwest of France where his father worked metal and sold hardware and lived well enough. No schooling in art did young Henri receive but instead worked forty years collecting tolls for the government, though some took to calling him customs man which he wasnt. His first wife Clémence died after watching eight babies go to their graves and left him with just Julia, their daughter, and a grief that sat in him like stone. He took up the brush then seeking something like salvation in paint and canvas.

Unlike them that painted peasants with romantic notions Rousseau painted what he knew and dreamed what common folk dream. He worked in the shadow of giants, starting late with no learning while others like Matisse had already staked their claims in the art world. Gordon who wrote about such things said Matisse feared painting like others while Rousseau yearned for it, wanted nothing more than to make something so proper and right that the Artiste Français would open their doors to him at last.

He sat there thinking on them that came before, them that spoke of truth and beauty being bound together like brothers in blood. Reckoned there was something to that. Old Keats had written it down plain as day on that ancient urn, said beauty was truth and truth beauty and that was all any man needed to know in this world. Most things a man learns come from books or hard living but these things, these notions of right and beauty, they come different. Like they was already there waiting.

We dont make the rules for what's right or what's beautiful, he thought. We just try to understand them after they already been made. Like trying to describe why a thing is good or why it aint. Take that painting of the woman with the strange smile. Men could talk about light and shadow and what it meant in its time but that wasnt it. That wasnt it at all.

When folks speak of things they love they always start the same way. There's just something about it, they say, before they try to explain with bigger words. But you cant never really explain it all. That woman O'Connor knew it. Said some things can only be told in stories cause regular words aint enough. Even when you describe every blessed thing about a book there's still something else. Something that aint got no words. Morality's the same way. Like that feller Wittgenstein said, you cant speak it proper. It's beyond speaking.

He thought on how both these things, what's right and what's beautiful, they hit a man someplace deep. Someplace you cant point to. Someplace beyond knowing but not beyond feeling. And when it comes to books, well. McKean had it right. Books aint like music or painting. Books carry the weight of right and wrong same as life does. Cant escape values when you're living and cant escape them in stories neither. That's why they matter. That's why they always will.

The land stretched vast and cold beneath a colorless sky, from the shadow-wreathed peaks of München to the slate waters of Kiel where the Baltic lapped at ancient shores. This was Germany. The same blood coursed through the veins of those who dwelt by the Rhine at Köln as those who walked the stone streets of Dresden where the Elbe cut its path. A people carved from many, yet bound as one.

Germania they called it in the old tongue. The name itself lost to time like footprints in shifting sand, though men argued still over its meaning. Tacitus, that Roman who put words to parchment, spoke of the Tungrians who crossed the Rhine, becoming Germans in the telling. And Caesar before him, who first scratched Germanus into his accounts of war, took it from the Gauls he'd broken. Some said it meant neighbor in that dead language. Some said it came from the spears they carried, dark wooden ger that drank deep of blood. Or maybe it rose from their battle cries that echoed across the forests like the howls of wolves.

Tacitus wrote of them in his time, ink flowing black as pitch across the page. Aboriginal, he named them. Untouched. Pure as winter snow. Who would come to such a place, he asked, with its wild woods and bitter skies? What man would choose such darkness unless born to it?

The Romans came though. Not to stay but to take. They sent their legions forth into those shadowed lands for amber and iron and flesh for their armies. They came and went like ravens to carrion, while the tribes remained. The Germans dwelt there in the borderlands, trading what the earth gave up to them, selling their sons to march beneath Roman eagles. They endured. They waited. The land was theirs and would remain so when Rome was dust.

The play spoke of masks and lies and the dark truth that a man who wears another's face too long might forget his own. He might wake one morning and find himself gone entirely. Yet to cast off such deceits meant to stand naked before those you'd fooled and some would forgive while others would curse your name into the cold night air till the stars fell.

When they changed their skin to wear another's gender it was a deeper thing. A more troubling thing. Like Viola who shed her woman's garments like a snake its skin, seeking shelter in manhood's guise. "I'll bring you to a captain in this town," she said, her words falling like dead leaves. "Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help I was preserved to serve this noble count."

She walked the razor's edge between worlds, cut off from sisterhood, adrift in a foreign land. And Olivia, God help her, saw only what her eyes told her was true. "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay." The words hung in the air like smoke. Even Orsino felt the pull of something he couldn't name: "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times thou never shouldst love woman like to me."

There was something raw and primitive in how the deception peeled back layers of desire like old wallpaper, revealing what lay beneath. Olivia's heart beat for Cesario but was it the man she thought she saw or something deeper, something that lived in darker waters? When Sebastian appeared like some twin star in the night sky, she turned to him as if Cesario had been nothing more than a dream. "A sister, you are she," she said to Viola, and just like that the spell was broken, the disguise fell away like ash in the wind.

They all stood revealed in the harsh light of truth, each carrying their own deceptions like old wounds that wouldn't heal. The play showed us this mirror and asked us to look deep, to see what masks we wore, what lies we told ourselves in the dead of night when no one was watching.

They called it German rule but there wasnt nothing German about the way they killed. The Ovaherero and the Nama knew. They knew in their bones and in their blood and in the dust that covered everything. The dust that was maybe their own people ground to powder by German boots and German guns.

He studied the old papers. Yellowed things speaking of schools and learning but the words were like smoke, there and gone and meaning nothing at all. In the east where the sun rose there were African men who could read and write and cipher numbers but in the southwest there was mostly just death and missionaries wandering like lost prophets in the desert vastness. The government built schools for the white children. Fine buildings of stone and wood but for the black children there was nothing. Nothing but dust and wind and the endless sky that didnt care what color a man was.

The land itself was a kind of school. Teaching things that no book could tell. How to die slow in the desert heat. How to watch your children waste away while white men sat in wooden houses drinking coffee and reading newspapers from Berlin. Fifteen thousand of them by 1913. White faces in a brown land. More than anywhere else in all their stolen empire.

He thought about the numbers. Numbers that meant nothing and everything all at once. Five thousand whites in East Africa where the ground was rich and green. Fifteen thousand in the southwest where nothing grew but hate. The missionaries came with their bibles and their promises but their words fell dead in the dust like everything else.

He'd seen papers written about it all. German papers mostly, old things that smelled of mold and forgetting. Later there were English words too, trying to make sense of it all. But there wasnt no sense to be made. Just the story of men who thought they could own the world and other men who learned different. The hard way. The dead way.

Cohen wrote about it. Wrote about the schools and the settlers and why things were different here than there. But maybe it was simpler than all that. Maybe it was just that some places collect darkness like others collect rain. And South West Africa had collected more than its share.

They came across the border like specters in the night, these two nations locked in their dance of death. Fifty-seven years they fought and bled, from 1836 when the first shots rang out across Texas until 1893 when the last echoes died away in the desert air. The war of '46 marked their darkest hour, American boots marching south through Mexican dust, claiming land that stretched far as any man could see. Texas and the Southwest territories fell like ripe fruit into American hands, though the blood price was dear.

The hatred ran deep as a mineshaft. Different gods, different tongues, different ways. Each side carrying old wounds from Spanish and English fathers long dead, wounds that wouldn't heal. Like neighbors everywhere who share a fence and precious little else, they found reasons enough to kill.

South of the border lay Catholic crosses and old monarchies, while north stood Protestant churches and democracy, though neither side could claim clean hands. The division between them was like the border itself - stark and unforgiving as the desert sun. Not unlike that later war between America and the Soviets, where men killed each other over ideas written in books they'd never read.

Seventeen times they clashed proper in those fifty-seven years, though the real number was higher if you counted every raid and counter-raid along that ragged wound they called a border. Bandits and outlaws moved like coyotes between the two lands, striking at towns on both sides until finally both nations sent their armies to restore what passes for peace in such places.

The old rivalry died slow, like everything else in that hard country. Mexico grew dependent on American coin, and American eyes turned from taking land to taking profit. The guns fell silent but the memory remained, carried in the wind that blows eternal across that stark dividing line, whispering of old hatreds and older blood. Some say you can still hear it, if you listen close enough on a quiet night.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like most afflictions but sudden and complete, like a door slamming shut in the dark. I didn't even know such a thing existed until it had me in its grip.

I was a nurse then. Chose it out of some deep hollow need for security that childhood never gave. They'd say you'll always find work cause folks'll always get sick and dying. So I buried my dreams of science and words and took up with the sick and dying instead.

Then there I was. Forty-six years lived and alone with nothing much saved and work became a memory. Still am broke down these days. Fifteen years living off government handouts leaves a person with nothing to call their own. Each dawn brings its own battle against fear and shame and uncertainty. Nothing stays fixed no more but one truth remains standing like a dead tree in a burned field - I wouldn't have made it without my people, my blood kin and the few true friends. When the darkness comes it strips away what strength you thought you had.

Truth is there'll always be calamity waiting. Big or small don't matter none. No amount of preparing can shield you when the real storms hit. Too big to weather alone.

People talk about getting free of government's rotting grip and I reckon they're right enough. But better we learn to trust each other again than go digging holes in our yards like scared animals. Better we learn to ask for help and give it too.

They preach about rugged individuals building this land but that ain't the truth of it. What kept our ancestors breathing through the hard times was mercy and respect and sharing what little they had. Them pioneers crossing the mountains didn't make it alone.

So make ready if you want. I done it myself. Got my survival kit with bandages and water tablets and plastic for the windows if the air goes bad. Got lights and batteries and matches sealed against water and food in tins. If you got land to farm and knowledge to keep food through winter then do it. Good idea same as having a wood stove, less you're stacked in apartments like cordwood.

But while you're fixing to survive, know your neighbors. Cause in the end that's all any of us really got.

In the old world, in lands far east where the sun first rises, there lived a prince. They called him Buddha later but that wasnt his name then. Not his true name. He walked out from his palace one night leaving all he knew behind him like a snake shedding its skin and when he came back he wasnt the same man that left. Maybe he wasnt a man at all anymore.

The things he spoke of grew like weeds in mens minds. Twenty five hundred years they grew. Changed and twisted. You could see it in Sri Lanka where they cut the waters now. Monks in their robes like old wraiths moving through the ceremony. The Buddha never spoke of such things but there they were all the same. The world changes what it touches. Even holy things. Even stone.

The changes came from within and without. Some meant harm and others didnt. Like wind wearing down a mountain. Like water cutting through rock. They all left their mark.

Words have power. Internal. External. Hostile. Benign. These words were important. Internal meant those who followed the Buddha's way. External meant those who didnt. Hostile meant those who'd tear it all down. Benign meant those who didnt care either way but changed things all the same. The words would come again and again like a hammer striking an anvil.

At its heart the religion was simple things. Three jewels they called them. The Buddha himself. The Dhamma which was his word written down in three parts like a tree with three branches. The Sangha which was the people who followed. The writings spoke of deep things. No soul. Suffering that cant be escaped. Nothing lasts. These were the truths they found. Hard truths like iron. They said a man could break free of dying and being born again. Could shed desire like an old coat. Could let go of hate. Could see clear through delusion like looking through clean glass.

They had rules. Five for common folk. Dont kill. Dont lie. Dont steal. Dont misuse the flesh. Dont poison the mind with drink. The monks had more. Many more. But at the bottom of it all were four truths. Life is suffering. Want causes suffering. Suffering can end. There is a way out.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced.
